The AlarmClock refers to a self-built alarm clock based on an ESP-32 microcontroller. This app serves for remote control and configuration of the alarm clock. The clock provides a REST web server within the local network, through which the app communicates with the clock.

The app essentially consists of 5 main screens: The home screen provides an overview of important values. The alarm settings allow for configuring the two alarms. The light control enables manipulation of the built-in light. The sound player manages sound playback. The sound list allows for editing saved sound labels.

The app itself doesn\'t store the alarm clock data; instead, it loads data through the REST API. Data fetching occurs automatically when the app is launched. After that, this process can be manually triggered. This can be done through the refresh icon in the top bar or by performing a pull-down gesture. Also after editing data, changes are automatically loaded from the server.
The start screen displays the current time of the clock, the next time the alarms will ring, the value of the ambient light sensor, and the elapsed time since the last restart of the clock.

In the alarm settings, parameters for the two fixed alarms can be adjusted. By clicking on the time, it can be set, and the alarm can be activated or deactivated using the switch. Below that, the days of the week on which the alarm should repeat can be selected. Clicking on the sound field allows assigning a specific sound to the alarm.

The light control allows manipulation of the clock\'s LED lighting. Brightness can be adjusted either by clicking on the brightness field or using the slider. The button can maximize brightness or turn it off. The light duration indicates how long the light will stay on before automatically turning off. This duration can be adjusted similarly to brightness.

In the sound player, a selected sound can be played or stopped. The sound can be chosen by clicking on the sound field. Below that, the volume of sound playback can be adjusted using the respective field or the slider.

The sound list exclusively displays the software-based labels of alarm clock sounds. These labels are independent of the sound files stored on the clock, to which a name is assigned through a fixed ID. The name of the sound is the label in the user interface and can be edited by clicking on it. Using the button on the side, it can be determined whether the sound should be included or excluded during random playback. Long pressing a sound allows moving it up or down or deleting it. A new sound can be added using the button at the end of the list.
